awd_titl_txt: EFRI CEE: DNA origami tools to engineer chromatin structure and function in live cells
awd_abstract_narration:
Numerous organisms from yeast to humans organize their genome by wrapping it repeatedly around histone proteins into nanoscale spools known as chromatin. Cells use the organization of chromatin to dictate whether a gene is actively expressed or turned off. Combining the ability to target a specific gene, visualize its location and structure, activate the gene, and detect gene expression in live cells would be a major technological advance in how genes are studied and controlled in living organisms, and lead to applications in many fields, including medicine, agriculture, energy and the environment. DNA nanotechnology, which uses well-understood folding properties of DNA to engineer nanoscale, biocompatible structures, is an emerging technology with the potential to combine these functions. A 5-PI team will apply bioengineering, cell biology, genetics, single molecule spectroscopy, super resolution microscopy and multi-scale molecular modeling to develop such DNA-based nanodevices that can also operate in live cells and be "switchable" to allow these functions to be triggered at will. The research will be integrated into university curricula, and will enable cross-disciplinary, collaborative and international training of graduate students. The PIs will also broaden participation of underrepresented students in STEM by creating open access standards-based videos and modules for use by K-12 teachers.

Recent advances in genetic and epigenetic methods have enabled chromatin engineering technologies that 1) target genes to 2) visualize chromatin structure, 3) activate target genes, and 4) detect gene-specific transcription. However, current tools (including super-resolution imaging, chromatin conformation capture and genome engineering with CRISPR/Cas9) are usually only able to accomplish one of these functions at a time, giving single-channel, static views of the players and processes at a specific transcription site. This project will leverage DNA nanotechnology to leapfrog current technologies for probing and engineering genome and epigenome functions. A team of five PIs will develop multi-functional DNA origami (DO) nanodevices that combine targeting, functional modifications and RNA detection onto a single platform, operate in live cell nuclei, and are "switchable", allowing for real-time detection and for functions to be triggered by endogenous or external signals. The outcomes will serve as a foundation for future automated devices that target and regulate genome and epigenome functions, including gene expression, and serve as diverse new toolsets for science, engineering, and medical applications.

This award is co-funded by the Genetic Mechanisms cluster in the Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences in the Biological Sciences Directorate, the Emerging Frontiers in Research and Innovation program in the Division of Emerging Frontiers and Multidisciplinary Activities in the Engineering Directorate, and the Chemistry of Life Processes program in the Division of Chemistry in the Mathematics and Physical Sciences Directorate.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Office of Emerging Frontiers in Research and Innovation (EFRI)

por.por_cntn:
The research project established methods to probe and control cellular behavior by developing DNA nanostructures that can be delivered to the nucleus of live cells. The work focused on delivering DNA origami nanostructures, which consist of a long single-stranded DNA strand, referred to as a scaffold, that is folded into a compact shape through binding interactions with many shorter single-stranded DNA strands. These binding interactions ultimately form bundles of double-stranded DNA helices in a compact nanostructure geometry. Important advantages of DNA origami nanostructures for applications in live cells include: 1) their precise nanoscale geometry; 2) they can be functionalized with a variety of molecules; and 3) they can carry genetic information in the DNA sequences. This work functionalized DNA origami nanostructures with antibodies that facilitate their delivery to the nucleus. Specifically, the nanostructures were functionalized with antibodies that target the intracellular molecule RNA polymerase, Pol II, which is naturally expressed outside the nucleus in the cytoplasm of cells and trafficked to the nucleus during normal cell function. When the antibody functionalized nanostructures are delivered into cells, they bind the Pol II molecule in the cytoplasm, and then are carried, or piggybacked, into the nucleus along with the Pol II. The DNA origami structures were also functionalized with several fluorophores to allow for monitoring their location and movement inside of cells. This approach was tested with several sizes of DNA origami nanostructures, and experiments revealed that nanorods approximately 30 nanometers in length are efficiently delivered to the nucleus and can remain structurally intact for 24 hr or more. These results establish a foundation for future applications where nanostructures can be used for imaging of manipulating processes in live cell nuclei.

The research project also demonstrated that DNA origami nanostructures can carry genetic information into cells, which can then be expressed into proteins. For this work, DNA origami nanostructures were folded from sequences that encode the expression of fluorescent proteins, and these nanostructures were functionalized with Cas9 proteins, which guide the nanostructures to a specific genome location where the genetic information can be incorporated and expressed. These studies demonstrated that various genes can be folded into compact nanostructures that can be delivered to cells and still be expressed by the cell, providing a unique approach that can be further developed for gene delivery applications.

Overall, the results establish a basis for DNA-based tools and devices that can be used for intracellular applications, especially inside the nucleus. The work involved close integration of design and biochemical functionalization of nanodevices guided by computational modeling and multiple modes of experimental characterization, which led to methods that can be widely adapted for using DNA origami nanostructures inside live cells. Furthermore, this highly interdisciplinary work provided unique training to several undergraduate, graduate, and post-doctoral researchers. The results and methods were disseminated through publications, conference presentations, and workshops organized by the research team. Finally, the research was also leveraged to support the training of a larger group of undergraduate students through the development of a combined research and entrepreneurship training program that engaged over 40 students in 4 years.

 


Last Modified: 02/12/2025
Modified by: Carlos E Castro
